intro: Acaena sericascens var. tenuibracteolata, commonly known as the slender bract acaena, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It is a member of the Rosaceae family and is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming habit. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are followed by distinctive, spiny fruits. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and covered in fine, silky hairs. It thrives in coastal and dry environments, often found in dunes and rocky areas.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena sericascens var. tenuibracteolata is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the North Island and parts of the South Island. This variant is commonly associated with coastal and lowland habitats. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in dunes and scrublands. The plant is part of the New Zealand flora and is adapted to the local climate and soil conditions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena sericascens var. tenuibracteolata was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and growth habit. However, it has since become naturalized and is now considered a weed in certain areas. The plant spreads through seeds and can colonize disturbed soils and open habitats. Its introduction has led to ecological concerns due to its potential to invade native vegetation.
